And the gates of darkness open of their own accord.
Transgressions and offenses are absolved,
And favor, rank, and fortune are bestowed anew.

An amnesty descends from heaven, releasing faults and pardoning errors;
Fortune flows from the true Dao, preserving life and extending destiny.
The gates of darkness are broken, and one is elevated beyond the common;
The light of grace shines upon them, and their name is inscribed with rank and emolument.

---

**Twenty-Third Oracle of the Hour of Xu – Meeting a True Friend – Most Auspicious**

A treasure long buried in the earth,
Its radiance now pierces the stars.
One who can recognize its worth
Will ascend the terrace of the immortals.

A qilin is trapped pulling a salt cart—without Bo Le, it cannot be known;
A beautiful jade is hidden in rough stone—without Bian He, it cannot be discerned.
Meeting a true friend, one’s talents may be revealed and their person elevated;
Encountering a lofty sage, one’s Dao may be illuminated and made clear.

---

**Twenty-Fourth Oracle of the Hour of Xu – False Words and Empty Trust – Most Inauspicious**

False words and idle speech abound,
Vain and devoid of truth.
Rumors spread, yet nothing is certain—
All remains unclear in the end.

One speaks falsely, and many repeat the falsehood.
The fabricator turns nothing into something, disrupting truth with deception;
The transmitter inverts right and wrong, misleading the ears of the multitude.

---

**Twenty-Fifth Oracle of the Hour of Xu – Seizing the Moment – Neutral**

A hundred blossoms bloom in fragrant splendor,
The spring flowers in full, resplendent display.
The Lord of Spring bestows his touch—
Why fear delay in affairs?

Plants that do not meet spring cannot sprout or bloom;
People who do not meet their time cannot unfold their aspirations or express their feelings.
When the season arrives, the Lord of Spring adorns all things with glory;
When fate flows smoothly, the halls of state bestow their molding grace.

---

**Twenty-Sixth Oracle of the Hour of Xu – Unobstructed Success – Most Auspicious**

Reform brings renewal,
The rivers and mountains shine under a bright sun.
Before one’s eyes, boundless vistas unfold—
A life of carefree joy and contentment.

The Dipper’s handle turns to *yin*, heralding the renewal of the tripod;
Spring’s light graces all things, a time of fragrant flowers and swaying willows.
With the world before one’s eyes radiant and clear, why not laugh and wander freely?
When the weight of worry is suddenly lifted, what hinders joyful roaming?

---

**Twenty-Seventh Oracle of the Hour of Xu – Attaining Rank and Emolument – Most Auspicious**

Dust is swept away without a trace,
Robes and cap, learning and conduct—all made new.
Only then can the great Dao be attained,
And the blue clouds will not be betrayed.

The sacred terrace is swept clean, not a speck of dust remains;
Learning surpasses all others, and one is certain to claim the highest honors.
Robes and cap command respect and reverence;
Achievements are fulfilled, and one attains the supreme glory of the imperial examinations.

---

**Twenty-Eighth Oracle of the Hour of Xu – Incompatibility – Most Inauspicious**

Do not attempt to carve unyielding stone,
Nor plant a withered willow.
The petty lack great capacity—
What is past cannot be undone.

One of small capacity cannot bear great responsibility;
One of low wisdom cannot discourse on lofty matters.
Unyielding stone cannot be carved into jade—efforts are wasted;
Withered wood cannot take root—watering and tending are in vain.

---

**Twenty-Ninth Oracle of the Hour of Xu – Worries Dissipate – Neutral**

Endless worries linger,
Yet no trace or cause is seen.
One must await the turning of the seasons—
Anxieties will flow away like water.

Prolonged indecision is called worry;
Fear of impending misfortune is called anxiety.
Worries dissolve like clouds scattered by a violent wind;
Anxieties vanish like waves carried away by the current.

---

**Thirtieth Oracle of the Hour of Xu – Ghostly Worries and Anxieties – Most Inauspicious**

Night rain weeps at the secluded window,
Wind and cold, the rain lashes fiercely.
Sleep eludes, and one cannot rest—
Other sorrows weigh even heavier.

At the secluded window, ghosts weep—malevolent spirits invade the household;
Through the long night, wind and cold—illness and misfortune cling to the young and weak.
When affairs are in disarray, sleep is restless;
When the heart is grieved, actions are troubled.

**Thirtieth Oracle of the Hour of Xu – Path Ahead Unobstructed – Most Auspicious**

Phoenix and crane roam free in leisure,
Wind pure, moon high above.
An immortal points the way—
The celestial path stretches far and wide.

Creation’s essence is flawless, free from harm or decay;
Cultivation perfected, one is sure to meet a true immortal.
Phoenix and crane ascend, soaring through the clouds;
Wind and moon shine clear, illuminating heaven and earth.

---

**First Oracle of the Hour of Hai – Upholding the Dao to Attain Truth – Most Auspicious**

Profound words are not easily grasped,
True immortals are seldom encountered.
With wholehearted devotion and reverence,
All eight directions open smoothly.

Words harsh to the ear, unadorned, are called loyalty;
Sweet, pleasing speech that misses the mark is called cunning.
Devotion to the Dao brings completion of merit;
The eight paths open, immortality may be learned, truth may be met.

---

**Second Oracle of the Hour of Hai – Breaking Free to Ascend – Most Auspicious**

Wings spread to rise to the lofty tree,
Soaring in triumphant flight.
Riding the wind, borrowing its force,
One leaps to the celestial pond.

Emerging from the dark valley to the towering heights—
A time of ascent and fulfillment.
Losing at dawn, gaining by dusk—
A moment of divine favor and joy.
Leaping to the celestial pond across ten thousand miles,
Riding the wind’s aid in an instant.

---

**Third Oracle of the Hour of Hai – Guidance to Avoid Delusion – Most Auspicious**

The emerald stream flows long,
The path to Peach Blossom Spring is distant and faint.
Without another’s guidance,
How could one encounter true light?

Clinging to thoughts is called delusion;
Deviant intentions are called error.
Following the emerald stream to Peach Blossom Spring—
The lost path gradually clears.
Inverted and perilous, seeking the profound—
Knowing the return, the misguided heart awakens.

---

**Fourth Oracle of the Hour of Hai – Overreaching Ambition – Most Inauspicious**

Firefly vies with moonlight,
How vast the difference in scale!
Wasting spirit and strength,
Only to be mocked in the end.

A single leaf of a boat cannot bear the weight of ten thousand jun;
A shallow pool cannot stir waves a hundred feet high.
Wisdom and insight dull, unfit for the court’s halls;
Daoist practice lax, lacking the bone-structure of immortals.

---

**Fifth Oracle of the Hour of Hai – No Aid, No Hope – Most Inauspicious**

Without study, the Dao remains unknown;
Without cultivation, truth is not met.
Not a trace of effort—
Only an empty name in vain.

Merit and cultivation complete, one may ascend the Dao and attain immortality;
Learning and conduct refined, how could official rank and glory be absent?
Yet with neither virtue nor learning cultivated,
Hopes for wealth, honor, and fame are far off indeed.

---

**Sixth Oracle of the Hour of Hai – Clarity Emerges from Obscurity – Most Auspicious**

An ancient mirror, long dimmed,
Its radiance unheard of.
Once polished by another’s hand,
Beauty and ugliness stand revealed.

Dust and grime accumulate on the precious mirror—
Washed and polished, its brilliance revives.
Stagnation lifts from the good and kind—
With guidance, their spirit rejoices.
The mirror gleams pure, reflecting all things;
Destiny flows smoothly, names are made.

---

**Seventh Oracle of the Hour of Hai – Divine Protection – Most Auspicious**

Incense smoke ascends to the cinnabar heavens,
A single sincere thought reaches afar.
Every action brings success—
The divine presence shines clearly.

The treasure censer burns talismans, sincerity rises to the cinnabar heavens;
The pure chamber invites the true, intent remains free of deceit.
Every endeavor is blessed by heaven—none fail;
Every plan is guarded by the divine—fortune finds its home.

---

**Eighth Oracle of the Hour of Hai – Disaster Retreats, Illness Fades – Neutral**

Ghosts disperse, illness heals,
Sorrowful faces turn to smiles.
With sincerity, one answers heaven and earth—
Take care not to create new transgressions.

Malevolent spirits scatter, driven away by the power of the Dao;
Illness fades from the secluded chamber, shielded by true light.
Reverent and devout in offerings and good deeds,
Expiate misfortunes, give thanks—
Avoid wrongdoing, forsake all evil.

---

**Ninth Oracle of the Hour of Hai – Minor Troubles Unsettled – Most Inauspicious**

The moon wanes, not yet full,
A lone figure shuts the door.
Unable to straighten what is bent,
The young and weak fear peril.

The moon’s light wanes—
The household faces layer upon layer of danger.
Flowers wither and fall—
The young and weak meet repeated misfortune.
The self harbors hidden, crooked worries;
The household invites gossip, strife, and vexation.

---

**Tenth Oracle of the Hour of Hai – Discord and Strife – Most Inauspicious**

Tears fall, deeper and deeper,
Unfounded troubles press at the gate.
Only stillness brings fortune—
Avoid inviting calamity.

Murmurs and silence—
The heart holds pent-up sorrow.
Lips and tongues wag—
The household stirs with anxiety.
Strife arises from contention—
Restraint comes first.
Restlessness from disturbance—
Stillness is supreme.

---

**Eleventh Oracle of the Hour of Hai – Seizing Opportunity – Most Auspicious**

The boat sails with the favorable wind,
Many hearts united as one.

**Twelfth Oracle of the Hour of Hai – Encountering Auspicious Occasions – Most Auspicious**

Just in time for the fine festive season,
Blossoms bloom before the eyes.
Seizing the moment to act—
Favorable conditions make it as easy as rolling a wheel.
A boat gliding downstream with the wind—
Swift as a galloping steed.
Facing the propitious hour and joyous festival,
Willows unfurl and flowers burst forth.
Gathering old friends and new companions—
Hearts in accord, minds in harmony.

---

**Thirteenth Oracle of the Hour of Hai – Joy Extrema Breeds Sorrow – Most Inauspicious**

The wine cup empties, revelry fades,
The heart’s affairs remain tangled in mist.
Once a carefree wanderer,
Now trapped in stagnation and hindrance.
Excessive merriment and extravagance—
Wealth depleted, joy exhausted, sorrow takes root.
Indulgence and greed—
Sin reaches its limit, transgression invites calamity.
Once a free and unfettered soul,
Forced to don a sorrowful countenance.
Fortunate to be a joyful person,
Yet turning back to seek restraint.

---

**Fourteenth Oracle of the Hour of Hai – Awakening from Delusion – Neutral**

The heart holds unspoken burdens,
Groans and sighs come first.
If someone offers wise counsel,
Sobering up brings lightness and ease.
Delusion breeds obstinate views—
Understanding dissolves them, clarity dawns.
Receiving a rare word of advice—
Like gifting a hundred *yi* of fine gold.
Gladdening the heart—
As if drinking a cup of rich, creamy milk.

---

**Fifteenth Oracle of the Hour of Hai – Schemes Lacking Certainty – Most Inauspicious**

The mind like a crow in the clouds,
The heart like duckweed on the water.
Wild tracks leave no trace—
How can subtle plans come to fruition?
A crane soaring in the sky—
Its flight path cannot be relied upon.
Duckweed drifting on the water—
Its movements cannot amass wealth.
What is schemed will surely fail—
Rising only to fall in vain.
What is employed will surely falter—
Laboring in futility.

---

**Sixteenth Oracle of the Hour of Hai – Plans Meet Obstruction – Most Inauspicious**

Ten words barely form a plan,
Yet deliberation must come first.
Do not act lightly—
Lest it end in mockery.
Those who scheme in secrecy and deceit—
Are called treacherous.
Those who devise ingenious strategies—
Are called tacticians.
Tactics misapplied, plans unused—
Turn and bring lingering misfortune.
Matters unexamined, schemes unfulfilled—
Only invite others’ ridicule.

---

**Seventeenth Oracle of the Hour of Hai – First Arrival, Later Success – Neutral**

A broken wing falls from the crimson sky,
Yet the one obstacle to soaring has vanished.
Better still to nurture sharpness—
Rising again will not be laborious.
A bird with a broken wing—
Loses the edge of its soaring flight.
A person who loses resolve—
Grows remorseful, lazy, and ashamed.
Feathers mended anew—
Will there not be a return to the heavens?
Aspirations and endeavors renewed—
Must hold the promise of smooth passage.

---

**Eighteenth Oracle of the Hour of Hai – Losing Control, Affairs Entangled – Most Inauspicious**

Reliance must lead to loss,
Trusting others will end in peril.
Vainly offering wealth and profit—
Only inviting right and wrong.
Aligning with power—
Like leaning on an ice mountain.
The sun’s first rays—
Ice melts, the mountain crumbles.
Lightly trusting others—
Like grasping at clouds and mist.
A sudden gale—
Mist scatters, clouds disperse, wealth vanishes, and disputes arise.

---

**Nineteenth Oracle of the Hour of Hai – No Affairs Can Prosper – Most Inauspicious**

The blind cannot walk,
The mute have no voice.
Both blind and mute—
Neither speech nor action can succeed.
Schemes unfulfilled—
Like the blind seeing the tiniest detail.
Hopes dashed—
Like the mute singing a melody.
If sight cannot see and speech cannot sound—
How can actions ever come to fruition?

---

**Twentieth Oracle of the Hour of Hai – Encountering the Noble, Affairs Prosper – Most Auspicious**

Towering ancient trees stand tall,
Their beams and pillars not far off.
Waiting for the right time, meeting a skilled craftsman—
Kindred spirits gather in harmony.
Upright and sturdy timber—
A fine artisan selects it for beams and pillars.
Loyal and worthy scholars—
Heavenly officials choose them for rank and emolument.
High talent and great renown—
Kindred spirits naturally meet.
Broad learning and deep virtue—
Like-minded discernment must align.

---

**Twenty-First Oracle of the Hour of Hai – Encountering the Time, Receiving Aid – Most Auspicious**

The moon reaches mid-autumn night,
Flowers bloom in the second month of spring.
At this moment, celebrate and rejoice—
A hundred blessings all made new.
On mid-autumn night, the moon—
A round osmanthus shadow.
In the second month of spring—
Ten thousand blossoms in brocade splendor.
Celebrating the auspicious occasion, feasting together—
A hundred blessings arrive at the gate.
Facing the fine night, delighting in purity—
A thousand auspicious signs gather at the door.

---

**Twenty-Second Oracle of the Hour of Hai – Losing the Time, Few Encounters – Most Inauspicious**

After mid-autumn wind and rain,
The moon dims, its radiance lost.
Sitting alone in the empty courtyard,
Silent, sorrow wells within.
Wind and rain obscure the mid-autumn moon—
The toad’s glow remains unstrung.
Obstruction and setback crush the scholar’s heart—
Only meeting with blockage and misfortune.
Guarding the empty courtyard alone—
Silent, wordless.
Dwelling in a humble abode, losing the time—
Deep, lingering resentment.

---

**Twenty-Third Oracle of the Hour of Hai – Correcting Errors, Attaining Peace – Neutral**

Forced to climb a high mountain,
Travelers struggle with every step.
If one can take the level path—
No need for schemes and tricks.
How can a person be without fault?
Knowing one’s faults and correcting them—
Renewing oneself.
How can affairs not be difficult?
Experiencing difficulty first—
Ease follows.
Upholding the right path—
Naturally at peace with one’s lot.
Resorting to schemes—
Only entangles oneself.

---

**Twenty-Fourth Oracle of the Hour of Hai – Troubles Yet Unsettled – Most Inauspicious**

Tigers chase the flock in haste,
Wind scatters withered leaves in frenzy.
Even in stillness, peace eludes—
How can one hope for success?
Panicked and disoriented—
Like a fierce tiger chasing a flock of sheep.
Tumbling and chaotic—
Like a violent wind scattering withered leaves.
The heart seeks stillness but remains unsettled—
Residual matters still entangle.
The mind seeks peace but remains disturbed—
External and internal turmoil persist.

---

**Twenty-Fifth Oracle of the Hour of Hai – Few Aids, Little Success – Most Inauspicious**

At the crossing, no boat or oar,
On land, the cart’s wheel breaks.
Unable to aid one another—
Relying only on one’s own strength to press forward.
Without boat and oar—
One cannot cross the water.
Without wheel and hub—
The cart cannot move.
The plight of few aids—
At the crossing, sinking in confusion.
The intent of no success—
On level ground, wheels break and progress halts.

---

**Twenty-Sixth Oracle of the Hour of Hai – First Sorrow, Then Joy – Most Auspicious**

How swiftly the violent storm arrives,
Thunder and lightning suddenly strike with alarm.
For a moment, Heaven’s will assists—
The moon shines bright, the air grows clear.
Violent rain and fierce wind—
Peach and plum bear the intent of ruin.
Rolling thunder and flashing lightning—
Fish and dragons tremble in shock.
The wind stills—
The moon shines bright, the air grows clear.
The clouds disperse—
Flowers bloom red, willows turn green.

---

**Twenty-Seventh Oracle of the Hour of Hai – Achievement and Dao Aligned – Most Auspicious**

**Twenty-Seventh Oracle of the Hour of Hai – Cultivating the Body and Guarding the Dao – Moderately Auspicious**

The true dragon and tiger are nurtured,
White snow and gold are refined.
When merit is complete, gods and ghosts lend aid—
Riding a crane, one ascends to explore the clouds.
The true dragon and true tiger coil within the precious tripod,
White snow and yellow sprouts irrigate the cinnabar field within.
When the Dao abides in unified qi, one becomes a person of long life and enduring vision;
When merit fills the three thousand, one joins the company of those who ride cranes and mount whales.

---

**Twenty-Eighth Oracle of the Hour of Hai – Caution in Body and Guarding the Dao – Moderate**

A thousand jun stone sinks in water,
A bundle of dry grass meets flames.
Guard the heart, guard against loss—
Diligently study the remaining hours.
Excessive greed and desire are like a great stone drowning in the abyss,
Indulging nature and the heart is like wildfire burning withered essence.
The heart must be guarded with care, lest it give rise to the mechanism of misfortune;
The Dao must be followed without fail, holding fast to the principle of the hidden and the subtle.

---

**Twenty-Ninth Oracle of the Hour of Hai – Divine Perfection Offers Protection – Most Auspicious**

Of the ten thousand things, none are not bound by fate;
Poverty and success truly have their time.
When the Dao prospers and the Dao is at peace,
Your blessings will be prolonged.
Heaven and Earth cycle each according to its number,
The ten thousand things alternate, each in its season.
Those who revere truth and uphold integrity—public and private paths flourish;
Those who accumulate merit and practice goodness—sacred power aids and divine power protects.

---

**Thirtieth Oracle of the Hour of Hai – Encountering the Strange, Remaining at Ease – Moderate**

Seeing the strange, do not treat it as strange;
Facing the alarming, do not be alarmed.
Simply maintain a heart of uprightness—
Divine beings will guard your gate.
Encountering the strange and not treating it as strange, the strange will not bring misfortune;
Facing the alarming and not being alarmed, the alarming will not bring disaster.
Steady the will, settle the heart—form and spirit will naturally be at ease.
Wash away the perverse, cleanse the filth—your household will naturally be at peace.

---

**Thirty-First Oracle of the Hour of Hai – Recklessness Violates Heaven’s Principle – Moderate**

Six horses gallop, difficult to rein in;
Three corpses depart—do not pursue.
Simply uphold your fate with integrity—
The Creator will not oppose you.
The six horses are the six thieves of the body—guard and prevent them with care;
The three corpses are the three ghosts within—seek to expel and destroy them.
If the six thieves are not indulged, the body will surely be at peace and life will surely be prolonged;
If the three corpses are driven out, the Dao may be accomplished and immortality attained.

---

**Metal Phase – Do Not Advance, Await the Time – Most Inauspicious**

Vast and hazy, the sky is filled with clouds,
Deep and heavy, the signs of rain run thick.

The path winds through perilous mountain trails—
Pause now and keep to the post pavilion.
Desires unfulfilled like the sky’s hazy clouds,
Emotions pent like the weight of gathering rain.

Mountain paths twist and turn, hard to advance—guard your seat in the post pavilion;
My Dao is obstructed, unopened—confined within a secluded chamber.

**Wood Phase – Remove Obstruction, Prosperity Comes – Moderately Auspicious**

A waning moon sinks behind the western peaks,
Bell chimes echo far and wide.
From dreams I wake once more,
Composing my heart to the Dao’s expanse.

The moon sets beyond the western mountains, gradually sensing dawn’s approach in the east;
Bell tones resound afar, mingling with the jade clepsydra’s hastening drip.
From slumber I stir—dull confusion begins to clear;
With the Dao-heart’s release, lingering anxieties retreat.

**Water Phase – Blessings and Emolument Flow from High Source – Most Auspicious**

The red sun fills heaven and earth,
Cinnabar exalts the wondrous Dao.
Lofty names inscribed on jade tablets,
Abundant emolument bestowed upon governance.

The radiant sun ascends—all demons hide, myriad evils cower;
Majestic virtue towers—nine heavens exalt, three realms submit.
Jade tablets record it, summoning fortune and emolument;
Scriptures annotate it, granting longevity eternal.

**Fire Phase – Frugality Begets Blessing – Moderately Auspicious**

Disharmony must lessen peace,
Without restraint, how can ease come?
Vigilance and thrift should be cultivated,
Preserving the heart ensures wholeness.

Vital qi weakened, illness suddenly arises;
Wealth scattered, poverty inevitably follows.
Frugality brings abundance, blessings multiply, harmony endures;
Extravagance invites calamity—beware and desist.

**Earth Phase – Shedding White to Attain Green – Most Auspicious**

Office conferred with third-rank dignity,
Name and surname spread through celestial pools.
Near and far, people revere,
Even Heaven itself takes note.

Leaping the Dragon Gate, no fear of dashed hopes;
Reputation resounds in all directions, thunderous in might.
Shedding white hemp to don green cords—golden lists proclaim high renown;
Entering the Purple Tenuity, wielding the imperial tally—jade halls display illustrious rank.

*End of the Thirty-First Precious Oracle of the Mysterious and True, Spirit-Responsive Divination Strips*

chunks.original_text: 玄真灵应宝签 经名：玄真灵应宝签。 撰人不祥。 三卷。 底本出处：《正统道藏》正一部。 玄真灵应宝签序 始吾庙食剑岭所降，清河内传，落笔双松，凡所祷者，竟以梦应。 然未尝以签行於世，今正殿及家庆楼庙吏，率借佗签为苟且计，如十二真君签，即青城丈人观签，如易卦在家庆，尤无所证。 况夫川蜀行祠，祇作朱真人内外签耳。 今吾亲考较妙用，上自天文，下至地理，与夫运数之向背，物情之离合者，委嗣子等七人，巧譬善谕，以上中下各作成一百二十签，以十二时，每时各三十签，又以五行金木水火土辏成三百六十五签，以按周天三百六十五度之数，庶几士之向信者，随其愿力而各有所得焉。 九天开化主宰灵应帝君序。 九天开化主宰文昌帝君宝诰 至心皈命礼不骄帝境玉真庆宫，现九十八化之行藏，显亿千万种之神异，飞鸾开化於在在，如意救劫以生生，至孝至仁，功存者道儒释，教不骄不乐，职尽乎天地水官，功德难量，威灵莫测。 大悲大愿大圣大慈九天辅元开化主宰、司禄职贡举真君、七曲灵应保德宏仁大帝、谈经演教消劫行化更生永命天尊。 玄真灵应宝签卷上 子时第一　风云庆会　上上 喜遇升平日，加官诰命封。 前程无限好，仙女跨飞龙。 筑黄金之台座纳士招贤，拜丹诏之勋封酬功受爵。 攀龙附凤稳升碧汉之中，云集风生庆会紫霄之上。 子时第二　腾达有望　上上 青年人物好，智识胜萧何。 谋事探如意，眉濡喜色多。 车书混一文章礼乐俱兴，道德无强仁义忠信悉备。 去天尺五拜丹诏於金阶，不次之除受皇恩於玉陛。 子时第三　谨守勿失　中平 任使鹰鹯逐，防他虎豹威。 简居君子道，何处觅闲非。 鹰鹯之逐狡兔伏於山林，虎豹之威行客防於道路。 君子静於守道万祸不侵。 小人冗乱私心一谋不遂。 子时第四　待时必捷　中平 千里一将军，奇谋藏未伸。 浪高云卷处，血染战袍新。 英略之将得其谋则攻必胜战必克，才志之人遇其时则道必亨名必遂一。 将有谋而功捷不难，人得时而名超甚易。 子时第五　望事难成　下下 有口笑葫芦，求名费远图，水萍空浪泛，何日达天衢。 将无作有孜孜空费於精神，指实为虚念念谩劳於梦想。 求一事若浮云中呼雁，望一事如急浪裹飘萍。 子时第六　亲好两同　上上 风流王谢家，秦晋各争夸。 自是吹箫客，好簪呜凤花。 风流王谢堂前紫燕争飞，秦晋交欢池内彩鸳对偶。 乘鸾凤吹箫泛月天上遨游，讲亲好鼓瑟簪花人间欢乐。 子时第七　重迭有喜　上上 莲幕既初开，重登锦上台。 庆他龙虎会，杰出间生才。 称心之美如开碧沼之莲，乐意之欢若玩锦堂之景。 龙虎会登仙之质璞药就丹成，贤杰生济世之奇才安民辅国。 子时第八　更改则吉　中平 局促更何为，和融喜入时。 任机随处好，高下稳行之。 局促之心情不舒而意不畅，和融之景改则吉而动则安。 盖机缘之有分进达谋通，凡举用而无疑上和下顺。 子时第九　事多奸充　下下 一女既相逢，那堪二女通。 柢因随处碍，应使浪生风。 事多滞碍皆因三女相逢，处用差池盖谓众情不顺。 平水因风而起浪静中不宁，安居因动以生迍暗中诡诈。 子时第十　内外和同　上上 姻娅既相通，朋簪臭味同。 鱼书传尺素，留得几家风。
chunks.translated_text:
**The Mysterious True Spirit-Responsive Auspicious Oracle**

**Title:** *The Mysterious True Spirit-Responsive Auspicious Oracle*. Author unknown. Three scrolls. Source text: *Zhengtong Daoist Canon*, Orthodox Section, Part One.

---

**Preface to *The Mysterious True Spirit-Responsive Auspicious Oracle***

At first, my temple was nourished by the descent upon Sword Ridge, its transmission flowing through the Clear River. With brush in hand, I inscribed twin pines, and all who prayed received responses in dreams. Yet I never disseminated these oracles in the world. Now, the temple officials of the Main Hall and the Family Celebration Tower borrow other oracles as a makeshift measure—such as the *Oracle of the Twelve Perfected Lords*, which is merely the *Oracle of the Venerable Elder of Mount Qingcheng*, or the *Yi* hexagrams used in the Family Celebration Tower, which lack any true verification. Moreover, in the temples of Shu, they employ only the inner and outer oracles of the Vermilion Perfected Lord.

Thus, I personally examined and refined their wondrous applications, encompassing the celestial patterns above and the terrestrial principles below, as well as the fortunes and adversities of destiny and the unions and separations of human affairs. I entrusted this task to my seven heirs, who, with skillful analogies and clear explanations, composed one hundred and twenty oracles each for the upper, middle, and lower grades. These are arranged by the twelve earthly branches, with thirty oracles for each, and further aligned with the five phases—Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, and Earth—to form three hundred and sixty-five oracles, corresponding to the three hundred and sixty-five degrees of the celestial sphere. May those who seek faith find fulfillment according to their aspirations.

**Preface by the Sovereign of Revealed Transformation of the Nine Heavens, the Spirit-Responsive August Lord**

---

**Precious Declaration of the August Lord of Literary Destiny, Sovereign of Revealed Transformation of the Nine Heavens**

With utmost sincerity, we bow and pay homage to the Jade True Celebration Palace in the Imperial Realm of the Unyielding, where ninety-eight transformations manifest in concealment and revelation, and myriad forms of divine marvels unfold. Through the flight of the phoenix, transformation is revealed in every place; with boundless compassion, calamities are averted and life is preserved across generations. Utmost filial piety and benevolence, your merit spans the Dao, Confucianism, and Buddhism. Neither arrogant nor indulgent, your office fulfills the duties of the celestial, terrestrial, and aquatic officials. Your merit and virtue are immeasurable, your majesty and numinosity unfathomable.

**Great Compassion, Great Vow, Great Sage, Great Benevolence, Sovereign of Revealed Transformation of the Nine Heavens, True Lord of Official Rank and Imperial Examinations, August Lord of the Sevenfold Curve, Protector of Virtue and Vast Benevolence, Heavenly Worthy of Eternal Life Who Expounds the Scriptures, Teaches the Dharma, Dispels Calamities, Enacts Transformations, and Renews Existence.**

---

**Scroll One of *The Mysterious True Spirit-Responsive Auspicious Oracle***

**First Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Auspicious Gathering of Wind and Cloud – Supreme Fortune**
A day of ascending peace arrives,
With titles and decrees bestowed.
The future holds boundless promise,
As immortal maidens ride flying dragons.

A golden terrace is built to welcome scholars and summon worthies,
A cinnabar decree confers honors and rewards merit with noble rank.
Clinging to the dragon and phoenix, one ascends steadily into the azure heavens,
Where wind gathers and clouds arise in joyous assembly upon the purple empyrean.

**Second Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Prospects of Success – Supreme Fortune**
A youth of fine character,
Wisdom surpassing Xiao He.
Plans unfold as desired,
Brows relaxed with joy.

Carriages and documents unite under one script, literature and ritual flourish together,
Virtue knows no peer, benevolence and righteousness, loyalty and trust are all complete.
A mere foot and a half from heaven, one kneels to receive the cinnabar decree upon the golden steps,
An extraordinary promotion grants imperial favor at the jade throne.

**Third Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Guard Carefully, Lest It Be Lost – Moderate Fortune**
Though hawks and falcons are sent in pursuit,
Beware the tigers and leopards’ might.
Dwell simply in the way of the noble,
Where can one find idle wrongdoing?

Hawks and falcons chase the cunning hare, which hides in the mountains and forests,
The might of tigers and leopards deters travelers on the road.
The noble one remains tranquil in guarding the Dao, and myriad misfortunes do not encroach,
The petty man, restless and self-serving, finds even a single scheme unfulfilled.

**Fourth Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Success Comes in Due Time – Moderate Fortune**
A general of a thousand *li*,
Whose brilliant strategies remain concealed.
Where waves surge and clouds roll,
Blood stains the battle robes anew.

A general of heroic strategy, when his plans are realized, will surely triumph in attack and prevail in battle,
A person of talent and ambition, when the time is right, will find the Dao flourishing and fame achieved.
With strategy in place, victory is not difficult,
With the right moment, renown is easily surpassed.

**Fifth Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Hopes for Success Are Dim – Inferior Fortune**
A gourd’s laughter echoes,
Seeking fame through distant schemes.
Like duckweed adrift on waves,
When will one reach the celestial thoroughfare?

Claiming the nonexistent as real, one exhausts spirit in vain,
Pointing to reality as illusion, one wearies the mind with empty dreams.
Seeking one matter is like calling for geese amidst floating clouds,
Hoping for another is like drifting duckweed in rushing currents.

**Sixth Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Harmony Between Kin and Friends – Supreme Fortune**
The refined households of Wang and Xie,
The states of Qin and Jin vie in splendor.
A guest who plays the flute,
Adorns himself with phoenix blossoms.

In the halls of the refined Wang and Xie, purple swallows vie in flight,
In the pond of harmonious Qin and Jin, colorful mandarin ducks pair.
Riding the phoenix and playing the flute, one roams the moonlit heavens,
Discussing kinship and striking the zither, one delights in floral adornments among mortals.

**Seventh Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Repeated Joys – Supreme Fortune**
The lotus curtain has just parted,
Ascending once more to the brocade terrace.
Celebrating the dragon-tiger gathering,
Exceptional talents emerge.

Joy as boundless as the blooming lotus in the azure pond,
Delight as vivid as the scenery of the brocade hall.
The dragon-tiger gathering refines the elixir, and the immortal’s nature is perfected,
Exceptional talents arise to pacify the people and assist the state.

**Eighth Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Change Brings Auspiciousness – Moderate Fortune**
Why persist in cramped quarters?
Harmony and joy arrive in due time.
Entrusting to fate, all is well,
Whether high or low, proceed steadily.

A cramped heart finds no ease, and the mind is not at peace,
When the scene changes to harmony, movement brings stability.
For destiny has its allotted share—advance and plans will succeed,
In all undertakings, there is no doubt: above harmonizes, below follows.

**Ninth Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Affairs Fraught with Deceit – Inferior Fortune**
A woman already encountered,
How can a second be tolerated?
Only because obstacles arise everywhere,
Should one stir winds recklessly.

Affairs are hindered by the meeting of three women,
Circumstances go awry due to discordant sentiments.
Still waters rise in waves when wind blows—tranquility is disturbed,
A peaceful dwelling stirs into misfortune—deception lurks unseen.

**Tenth Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Internal and External Harmony – Supreme Fortune**
Affinal kin are already connected,
Friends share the same tastes.
Fish-shaped letters on silk,
Preserve the customs of many households.

chunks.original_text: 谐合姻□之好意合情通，和同馨味之欢谋宜事遂。 鱼雁得佳音而有喜内悦外和，家庭保福扫之荣昌上从下顺。 子时第十一　守否方泰　中平 剥尽复方生，时通路有亨。 谨身应不失，狂妄莫重行。 六阴至极阴极阳气始生，吾道至穷道穷变否为泰。 否与泰循环之理有盛有衰，阴与阳生杀之端有荣有谢。 子时第十二　所求阻隔　下下 久客无归路，津梁又失时。 望乡台上立，何见免岖崎。 羁旅之情远在天涯海角，求谋之意近逢水远山遥。 登岖崎绝有艰辛路危道险，望音信殊无通报鸦杳鱼沉。 子时第十三　前程大吉　上上 云散月重明，风恬浪不生。 岸高船自济，抚掌一家荣。 阴云忽散一轮明月现光辉，灾赛顿消万里前程平坦率。 进一事进无碍滞风浪恬然，谋一事谋有亨通欢歌抚掌。 子时第十四　占信有望　上上 灯结数层花，池莲发异葩。 柢因和气溢，佳信落天涯。 灯结花报天涯之喜信，池发莲称人事之欢心。 氤氲和气仰感万物之丰登，瑞霭祥云覆护一门之康泰。 子时十五　望外小喜　上上 幸结残花实，喜生枯树枝。 偶然春意在，双喜笑来迟。 庭前枯木忽生荣茂之柯，园内残花喜结桃梅之实。 望中事不期而就就则有成，心下虑偶尔而消消则无害。 子时第十六　大宜进望　上上 桂子十分香，琼瑶映碧堂。 更加风力便，攀附看翱翔。 琼瑶映玉乾坤发莹净之光，岩桂开金宇宙喷馨香之气。 风力便直冲霄汉万里翱翔，神物助俓达亨衢一身康泰。 子时第十七　图名遂意　上上 风激上青霄，鹏搏六翩秋。 尺书云外至，一举占鳌头。 图名通达如雕鹗飞奋於秋天，谋利亨嘉若莺燕娇吟於春圃。 风一激云开万里稳稳逍遥，举一事神助百祥平平遂意。 子时第十八　先滞后成　中平 后笑必先眺，宁无损一毫。 度舟应有济，江稳绝风涛。 先号咷而后笑悲极生欢，始赛塞而终通损中有益。 江稳者波平风静事泰心安，有济者时至运临脱灾出滞。 子时第十九　占福有余　上上 利剑若吹毛，云高山亦高。 此身无障碍，食息岂辞劳。 道弥德广高如齐岳之山，事快情通利若吹毛之剑。 有福力有谋必遂勿息勤劳，无障碍无所不通自然允济。 子时第二十　危迫无成　下下 牛后尾分岐，那堪鸡口悲。 望人人不见，回首事应迟。 牛乃力耕之物牛尾分则事失田荒，鸡为警旦之禽口生悲则门灾户扰。 所望者稽迟有滞，所用者迫逼不成。 子时二十一　望信两失　下下 无情恨食言，风险又无船，日暗应迷路，烟云遮碧天。 对暮春无情有恨花落水流，望长江有浪无船魂消魄散。 红日晚向迷归路戚戚忧心，碧云障犹隔天涯沉沉别意。 子时二十二　向进通达　上上 秋月十分圆，云开光满川。 家家浑不碍，江映一青天。 云开天净月华现玉鉴之无尘，灾退福生家门集金真之垂佑。 进向则有圆无缺光满十分，求利则无碍有成欢生一庆。 子时二十三　劳心事成　中平 矿尽见真金，苗长识土探，青云终有路，休恩苦劳心。 黄金出於矿石非烹炼不能成其宝，真仙生於凡胎非功行不能成其道。 耕耘得时稼穑登，勤劳勿惮谋用遂。 子时二十四　无欺有望　中平 月被浮云暗，鉴犹尘土侵。 若交无障碍，清却一丹心。 云藏月暗风吹云散月明，尘掩鉴昏人拂尘消鉴莹。 虽有侵欺之恼易释易除，更无唇吻之非保安保吉。

**Eleventh Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Holding to Adversity Before Prosperity – Moderate Fortune**
Harmony in affinal bonds—goodwill meets and sentiments flow,
Unity in shared tastes—joyful plans bring affairs to fruition.
Fish and wild geese bear glad tidings, delighting within and harmonizing without,
The household preserves its blessings, sweeping away misfortune—above follows, below obeys.

**Eleventh Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Holding to Adversity Before Prosperity – Moderate Fortune**
Stripped bare, renewal begins; when the time is right, the path opens.
Guard your conduct to avoid loss,
Recklessness must not be repeated.
Six yin reach their extreme—at the darkest hour, yang qi stirs to life,
The Dao, when exhausted, transforms: adversity turns to prosperity.
The principle of closure and openness cycles—there is flourishing, there is decline,
The mechanism of yin and yang—there is growth, there is decay.

**Twelfth Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Hopes Blocked and Obstructed – Inferior Fortune**
A long sojourner finds no road home,
Ferries and bridges miss their time.
Standing on the terrace gazing toward home,
What is seen but rugged peaks?
The traveler’s longing stretches to the ends of the earth,
Hopes for success meet rivers too distant, mountains too high.
Climbing perilous heights brings hardship—paths are treacherous, roads are dangerous,
Yearning for word brings only silence—no raven’s cry, no fish’s trace.

**Thirteenth Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Great Auspices Ahead – Supreme Fortune**
Clouds disperse, the moon shines anew,
Wind stills, waves do not rise.
The bank is high, the boat crosses of itself,
Clapping hands, the whole household prospers.
Dark clouds suddenly scatter—a full moon reveals its radiance,
Misfortune vanishes in an instant—a thousand miles lie smooth and level ahead.
Advance in one matter, advance without hindrance—wind and waves are calm,
Plan one thing, plan with success—joyful songs and clapping hands.

**Fourteenth Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Auspicious News Expected – Supreme Fortune**
The lamp forms layered blossoms,
The pond’s lotuses bloom with rare flowers.
Only because harmonious qi overflows,
Glad tidings arrive from afar.
The lamp’s blossoms herald distant joy,
The pond’s lotuses bring delight to human affairs.
The misty harmony of qi rises, blessing all things with abundance,
Auspicious clouds and propitious mists shelter the household with well-being.

**Fifteenth Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Unexpected Minor Joy – Supreme Fortune**
Fortune bears fruit from fading blossoms,
Joy sprouts from withered branches.
By chance, the breath of spring lingers,
A double delight arrives late with laughter.
The courtyard’s dead tree suddenly puts forth flourishing boughs,
The garden’s fading flowers happily bear peach and plum.
Hoped-for matters come unexpectedly to fruition—success is assured,
Anxieties dissolve by chance—harm is averted.

**Sixteenth Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Greatly Favorable for Advancement – Supreme Fortune**
Osmanthus seeds are richly fragrant,
Jade and jasper gleam in the jade hall.
With the wind’s aid,
Climb and soar.
Jade and jasper reflect the pure light of heaven and earth,
Rock osmanthus blooms, filling the cosmos with its golden fragrance.
The wind’s power carries one straight to the heavens—soaring for ten thousand miles,
Divine favor assists the journey—prosperity and peace attend the whole person.

**Seventeenth Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Aspirations Fulfilled – Supreme Fortune**
Wind drives upward to the azure sky,
The roc beats its six wings in autumn.
A letter arrives from beyond the clouds,
In one stroke, one seizes the turtle’s head.
Aspirations for fame soar like the osprey taking flight in autumn,
Plans for gain prosper like orioles and swallows singing in spring gardens.
One gust of wind scatters the clouds—a thousand miles of carefree ease,
One endeavor, with divine aid—all things proceed smoothly to fulfillment.

**Eighteenth Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Delayed Success – Moderate Fortune**
Laughter follows tears,
Yet not a hair is lost.
Crossing the boat will bring success,
The river is calm, free of wind and waves.
First wailing, then laughter—sorrow gives way to joy,
Beginning with obstruction, ending in success—loss brings gain.
When the river is calm, waves are stilled, wind is quiet—affairs are peaceful, the heart is at ease,
When there is deliverance, the time has come, fortune arrives—escaping disaster, emerging from stagnation.

**Nineteenth Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Abundant Blessings – Supreme Fortune**
A sharp sword cuts like a breath,
Clouds rise high, mountains rise higher.
This body knows no obstruction,
Why shirk labor in food and rest?
The Dao’s virtue spreads wide, high as the sacred peaks,
Affairs proceed swiftly, sharp as a sword that severs hair.
With blessings and strength, with plans—persevere without ceasing,
No obstructions, nothing fails to pass—naturally, all is accomplished.

**Twentieth Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Peril and No Success – Inferior Fortune**
The ox’s tail splits,
How can the chicken’s beak bear sorrow?
Hoping for someone, no one is seen,
Turning back, affairs will be delayed.
The ox, creature of plowing—when its tail splits, fields lie fallow,
The chicken, herald of dawn—when its beak grieves, the household faces calamity.
What is hoped for is delayed, obstructed,
What is pursued is pressed, unfulfilled.

**Twenty-First Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Hopes and News Both Lost – Inferior Fortune**
Heartless, resenting broken promises,
Wind and peril, yet no boat,
The sun darkens, the road is lost,
Mist and clouds veil the azure sky.
Facing late spring, heartless and resentful—flowers fall, waters flow,
Gazing at the Yangtze, waves rise, no boat—spirit fades, soul scatters.
The red sun sets, the way home is lost—sorrow weighs on the heart,
Azure clouds obscure, still separating—parting thoughts sink deep.

**Twenty-Second Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Advancing Toward Success – Supreme Fortune**
The autumn moon is perfectly round,
Clouds part, light fills the river.
Every household knows no hindrance,
The river mirrors a single blue sky.
Clouds part, the sky clears—the moon’s brilliance shines like a flawless mirror,
Disaster retreats, blessings arise—the household gathers golden truth’s protection.
Advancing brings wholeness, no lack—light fills to the full,
Seeking gain brings no obstruction—success and joy abound.

**Twenty-Third Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Laborious Success – Moderate Fortune**
Ore exhausted, true gold appears,
Shoots grow, the soil’s depth is known.
The path to blue clouds will open,
Do not sigh over toilsome labor.
Gold emerges from ore—without refining, it cannot become treasure,
True immortals are born of mortal flesh—without merit and practice, they cannot attain the Dao.
Timely cultivation brings bountiful harvests,
Diligent labor brings no fear—plans come to fruition.

**Twenty-Fourth Oracle of the Hour of Zi – No Deception, Hopes Fulfilled – Moderate Fortune**
The moon is veiled by drifting clouds,
The mirror is dimmed by dust.
If there is no obstruction,
A pure, single heart shines clear.
Clouds hide the moon, darkening it—wind scatters the clouds, the moon brightens,
Dust covers the mirror, dulling it—one wipes the dust, the mirror gleams.
Though there may be vexing deceptions, they are easily dispelled,
Without the harm of idle words—peace and good fortune are preserved.

chunks.original_text: 子时二十五　谋财有成　上上 珠玉富囊中，财粮亦自通。 不资人力助，其德日无穷。 粮食丰足六天之内一天，金玉盈箱五福之中一福。 食与财丰盈双美日益无穷，福与禄兴盛俱临时增有济。 子时二十六　用事有成　上上 培壅积年功，风云要发踪。 共开龙虎道，何日不侯封。 合抱之木块培非一日之功，侯爵之封升擢乃功勋之赏。 虎啸则风生满谷威大神全，龙吟则云布弥天轰雷致雨。 子时二十七　官事而解　中平 官事恐悠悠，淹留几月休。 但存公直理，方得免忧囚。 讼终凶而返吉勿恃勿欺，事先乱而后宁且谨且守。 理虽存於公道脱免为先，身当离於淹留免凶为上。 子时二十八　自执不通　下下 强弱谩纷纷，崎岖独掩门。 幽闲无活路，饥饿任黄昏。 不义不仁何异以强凌弱，多贪多欲有如倚富吞贫。 上下伤於和气独处幽闲，内外生於怨心兀居寒饿。 子时二十九　百事未遂　下下 船碍石中波，徒行惊渡河。 云高山亦险，愁寂奈情何。 谋心恐恐水中石碍行船，用意惶惶山下虎拦过客。 险阻者不能进步无力跻攀，困厄者惟起愁情何时通遂。 子时三十　祈福免灾　中平 自有菩提路，家家香火缘，欲逃罗网厄，疏朗一青天。 上善之人俓达菩提之路，修真之士超登快乐之门。 心无绾乱一身自脱网罗，意若谨持百事岂能拘碍。 丑时第一　求之必得　中平 得失自茫茫，闲愁虑更长。 莫辞勤着意，金玉再盈箱。 得失乃乘除之法不用关心，兴衰乃代谢之宜何劳着念。 事称遂未有不求而自至，稻丰熟岂有不种而自生。 丑时第二　事与心契　中平 红绿为留春，佳人情更亲。 按头香未断，歌笑草中茵。 契绿相合所事无不欢谐，识见和同所用自然亲好。 香未断再添新篆气象氤氲，酒未乾又续新杯人情悦择。 丑时第三　名职改迁　上上 阆苑一时春，庭前花柳新。 市城皆好语，草本亦欣欣。 春雷微震藏者动而垫者兴，阳气方生柳吐芽而花破萼。 好语者传佳音满国，欣颜者布欢信盈门。 丑时第四　财帛见喜　上上 忆昔伤时态，今朝花草春。 稻粮随处足，瓜李一时新。 时通运泰今者是而往者非，臈尽春回草自萌而花自发。 瓜李熟秀而得实共庆时新，稻粮足而家给岁丰普沾福庆。 丑时第五　病患临身　下下 天灾未可祈，力困岂能支。 三虫昂首立，非血不成悲。 重病未能痊瘥实乃天灾，沉愈尚自淹延岂非今遣。 况三虫而食血虑防虫毒之危，恐二口而冲心必致患危之厄。 丑时第六　小小见喜　中平 疏散任情真，花间谩染身。 笑吟灯烛夜，樽俎客相亲。 身疏散心除坚碍逸乐天真，道踪横意趣玄微逍遥人世。 狂花野草更无一点尘萦，列烛开筵自有百端亲好。 丑时第七　谨事小成　上上 莫愁空浪心，去去不消沉。 幸自逢时变，珍良喜获金。 驾商舟而图名利必不空回，凭货物以求资财必无消折。 待变者时昌岁泰无所不通，获金者利厚财丰无所不济。 丑时第八　药石无效　下下 探病入膏肓，难施扁鹊方。 药石非苦口，千里一难当。 病入膏育已有倒悬之危急，药修良剂更无神效之奇功。 虽卢医扁鹊不能施其方，纵妙药灵丹岂能救其困。 丑时第九　冤结不解　下下 秪为生荆棘，豺狼及子孙。 一庭灯烛夜，灰冷半星存。 刻棘生於怨恶祸及子孙，狂纵起於侈淫害临自己。
chunks.translated_text:
**Twenty-Fifth Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Wealth Gained in Plans – Supreme Fortune**
Pearls and jade fill the coffers,
Wealth and grain flow freely.
Not by another’s aid,
One’s virtue grows boundless day by day.
Grain abundant for six days—one day’s plenty,
Gold and jade overflowing chests—one blessing among the Five Fortunes.
Food and wealth flourish in double splendor, ever-increasing without end,
Fortune and rank rise together, bringing timely aid.

**Twenty-Sixth Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Success in Affairs – Supreme Fortune**
Years of nurturing build the foundation,
Wind and cloud await their moment to stir.
Together they open the Dragon-Tiger path—
What day will not bring a marquis’s seal?
A tree of great girth is not nurtured in a single day,
A marquis’s enfeoffment is the reward of meritorious deeds.
When the tiger roars, wind fills the valley—majestic power is complete,
When the dragon intones, clouds spread across the sky—thunder rolls, rain descends.

**Twenty-Seventh Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Legal Matters Resolved – Moderate Fortune**
Legal troubles stretch on endlessly,
How many months will the delay endure?
Only by upholding fairness and justice,
Can one escape the woes of imprisonment.
Litigation ends in misfortune yet turns to fortune—do not rely on deceit,
Affairs first in chaos, then in peace—be cautious and steadfast.
Though principle rests in righteousness, escape comes first,
To leave behind prolonged entanglement is the highest good.

**Twenty-Eighth Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Stubbornness Blocks Progress – Wretched Fortune**
The strong and weak clamor in vain,
Lonely and rugged, the door remains shut.
Secluded, with no path forward,
Hunger and cold endure till dusk.
Without righteousness or benevolence, how is this different from the strong oppressing the weak?
With greed and desire, it is like the rich devouring the poor.
Above and below, harmony is wounded—alone in seclusion,
Within and without, resentment arises—isolated in cold and hunger.

**Twenty-Ninth Oracle of the Hour of Zi – All Affairs Unfulfilled – Wretched Fortune**
The boat is hindered by rocks in the waves,
A traveler on foot fears crossing the river.
Clouds hang high, mountains are perilous—
In sorrow and solitude, what can be done?
Plans are fraught with fear—rocks in the water block the boat,
Intentions are anxious—a tiger at the mountain’s base bars the traveler.
Perils and obstacles prevent progress, no strength to climb,
Distress and hardship breed only sorrow—when will success come?

**Thirtieth Oracle of the Hour of Zi – Pray for Blessing, Avoid Disaster – Moderate Fortune**
The path of bodhi lies open,
Every household shares in the incense’s bond.
To escape the snare’s calamity,
A clear, boundless sky appears.
Those of utmost goodness swiftly reach the bodhi path,
Cultivators of truth ascend the gate of joy.
With a heart free of entanglement, the body escapes the net,
With mind held in reverence, how can affairs be hindered?

**First Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Seek and You Shall Obtain – Moderate Fortune**
Gain and loss drift in vagueness,
Idle worries stretch long.
Do not shirk from diligent care—
Gold and jade will fill the chests again.
Gain and loss follow the law of ebb and flow—no need for concern,
Rise and decline are the natural order—why trouble the mind?
No affair succeeds without seeking,
No rice ripens without planting.

**Second Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Affairs Align with the Heart – Moderate Fortune**
Red and green linger to keep spring,
The beauty’s affection grows deeper.
With hairpins still fragrant,
Laughter and song rise from the grassy mat.
Harmony in agreement—no affair is not joyful,
Shared insight—all uses naturally grow close.
Incense not yet burned, new coils add their fragrance, mist swirling,
Wine not yet finished, new cups are poured—hearts delight in choice.

**Third Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Promotion in Rank – Supreme Fortune**
Spring arrives in an instant in the celestial garden,
Before the courtyard, flowers and willows renew.
The marketplace buzzes with kind words,
Even grasses and trees rejoice.
The faint rumble of spring thunder—what was buried stirs, what was low rises,
Yang qi begins to flourish—willows sprout buds, flowers burst from calyxes.
Kind words spread good tidings throughout the land,
Joyful faces carry glad news to every door.

**Fourth Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Wealth and Silk Bring Joy – Supreme Fortune**
Once I grieved over the times,
Now spring blooms in the grass and flowers.
Grain is abundant everywhere,
Melons and plums ripen all at once.
The times are favorable, fortune prospers—now is right, the past is wrong,
The year’s end passes, spring returns—grass sprouts, flowers bloom.
Melons and plums ripen, bearing fruit—together we celebrate the new season,
Grain is plentiful, households are provided—universal blessings abound.

**Fifth Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Illness Befalls the Body – Wretched Fortune**
Heaven’s calamity cannot be prayed away,
Exhausted strength cannot sustain.
The Three Worms raise their heads—
Without blood, there is no end to sorrow.
A grave illness cannot be cured—it is truly heaven’s disaster,
A lingering affliction drags on—is this not fate’s decree?
Moreover, the Three Worms feed on blood—beware their venomous peril,
The Two Mouths may strike the heart—surely this brings mortal danger.

**Sixth Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Minor Joys Appear – Moderate Fortune**
At ease, following true nature,
Amid flowers, lightly adorned.
Laughing and singing in the candlelit night,
Guests gather around the feast in warmth.
The body is free, the heart unburdened—carefree in natural joy,
The path of the Dao winds through subtle mysteries—at ease in the world.
Wildflowers and grasses, untouched by a speck of dust,
Lamps lit, the banquet set—countless bonds of kinship.

**Seventh Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Cautious Affairs Bring Small Success – Supreme Fortune**
Do not fret over empty, restless thoughts,
Go forth—do not sink into despair.
Fortunately, the times change—
Precious treasures bring joy in gold.
Board the merchant’s boat to seek fame and profit—it will not return empty,
Rely on goods to seek wealth—there will be no loss.
Awaiting change, the times prosper, the year is favorable—nothing is blocked,
Gaining gold, profit is rich, wealth is abundant—nothing is left unfulfilled.

**Eighth Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Medicine and Stone Ineffective – Wretched Fortune**
The illness has entered the vital organs,
Even Bian Que’s methods cannot be applied.
Medicine and stone are not bitter to the mouth—
A thousand miles away, one remedy is hard to find.
The disease has reached the critical stage—hanging in peril,
Even refined medicine lacks miraculous effect.
Though Lu’s physician or Bian Que could not administer a cure,
Even the finest elixir or divine pill could not save the afflicted.

**Ninth Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Grievances Remain Unresolved – Wretched Fortune**
Only because thorns have grown,
Jackals and wolves now threaten even the descendants.
In the courtyard, the candlelit night—
Ashes grow cold, half a spark remains.
Thorns of resentment arise from hatred—calamity reaches the descendants,
Wild abandon born of excess and indulgence—harm befalls oneself.

The moon is veiled by drifting clouds,

If there is no obstruction,
A pure, single heart shines clear.
Clouds hide the moon, darkening it—wind scatters the clouds, the moon brightens,

chunks.original_text: 灯烛夜晦暗中用事事不可明，火存半星灰内求然然不能熟。 丑时第十　倍获厚利　上上 水高船自高，应手未尝劳。 已觉多多办，谁能较尔曹。 月明风静对秋月自现光辉，水长船高得顺水不劳撑驾。 多多益办如韩信之将兵，未尝辞劳若孔明之竭节。 丑时十一　大宜迁擢　上上 不是文章贵，安知望外迁。 若论清要地，身近紫薇垣。 文章高美名标金榜之中，学业精微身贵玉堂之内。 职居清要之地恩宠日隆，身近紫薇之垣光华易显。 丑时十二　有虚无实　下下 无形空抱影，平地生赘疣。 羁绊从我出，何日消百忧。 无形安得有影影自何生，无水焉得生波波从何出。 虚中无实事必是於妄传，实中有虚言必从於外说。 丑时第十三　久困渐安　中平 困龙久蟠泥，山低虎径迷。 渐攀云雾出，红日未平西。 蛟龙未得云雨困卧幽岩，豺虎迷失山林潜伏草莽。 君子凡居养道道亨则进达必通，士入修业待时时至则功名自显。 丑时十四　旅隔不堪　下下 多病几时苏，烟波隔远途。 马疲人又困，残日啸猿狐。 心不乐如患淹留之病，事不遂若隔巇崄之途。 马疲人困不能进而不能前，列日猿狐不可行而不可止。 丑时十五　贵人扶助　上上 一箭降清霄，途行逢马牛。 轮车通宝货，风急送行舟。 求名取禄遇荐举而进身＃１，蹈困途行得骏骋而堪代步。 宝货盈而车轮快速急若飞，云风水顺而舟楫稳平疾如奔骑。 丑时十六　进退两得　上上 一马过前山，金乌照远关。 高低无阻碍，歌舞映容颜。 金乌升於天汉照下朗明，骏马疾如追风前程通快。 欲上欲速高低皆可攀跻，欲进欲违上下并无拘执。 丑时十七　前程失望　下下 大雅何时见，斯文几日亨。 秪因愁白首，扪腹困诸生。 文章疏谬更无科甲之名，大雅荒亡空有留连之乐。 望功名而挫失白首无成，叹学业以蹉跎年华已老。 丑时十八　安静有得　中平 安分第一机，方识静中暮。 莫滞心头鉴，从他细管窥。 澄心静虑如通心下之机，定志颐神方识琴中之趣。 弃尘缘而勿滞鉴自分明，修圆觉以参微惠光自见。 丑时十九　作为暗昧　下下 佳人恨掩门，情隔不相通。 进退全无托，难寻正路踪。 佳人有恨虑防阴小不宁，情隔不通多主行藏赛塞。 暗昧事牵缠不已进退两疑，幽闷怀萦挠无休忧喜不定。 丑时二十　失事无成　下下 身在急难中，犹夸意气浓。 笑他无活路，人鬼怒相攻。 人居患难当修善以消攘，事在窘危宜谨心而避畏。 夸雄豪而不知命分挫失犹多，生妬害而欲损他人鬼神共怒。 丑时二十一　意外有喜　上上 云外降天书，门多长旨车。 香添兰室味，携手入蟾蜍。 丹书天降则思宠之光荣，长者车临庆门庭之贤贵。 事遂意如入芝兰馨香之室，谋称心如登广寒蟾桂之宫。 丑时二十二　人财遂意　上上 宝玉贵珍藏，年年粳稻香。 翠阴千里绿，桃李自成行。 宝山出现贵尺璧之奇珍，粳稻熟成庆丰登之乐岁。 事遂翠阴千里绿荫清和，财丰桃李成行花开结实。 丑时二十三　听时必达　中平 有物未周旋，生涯难复艰。 天时任消息，何地不闲闲。

**Tenth Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Doubled Profits – Most Auspicious**
In the murk of candlelit night, all affairs remain obscure,
A spark lingers in the ashes—though sought, it cannot ignite.

**Tenth Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Doubled Profits – Most Auspicious**
As water rises, the boat ascends—
All comes effortlessly to hand.
What need is there to measure gains?
Who could rival such fortune?

The moon shines bright, the wind still—autumn’s glow reveals its splendor,
The tide swells, the vessel rides high—no need to strain at the oars.
Abundance comes in multitudes, like Han Xin leading troops,
Never shirking labor, like Kongming’s steadfast devotion.

**Eleventh Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Great Favor in Promotion – Most Auspicious**
Not for the sake of fine prose is one exalted,
How could one know of an unexpected rise?
If one speaks of a coveted post,
The body draws near the Purple Tenuity.

Refined writings shine bright, names inscribed on the golden roll,
Scholarship profound, the self honored within the jade hall.
Holding office in a prized position, imperial favor grows daily,
The body nears the Purple Tenuity—radiance readily revealed.

**Twelfth Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Hollow and Substance-Free – Most Inauspicious**
No form yet clinging to shadows,
On level ground, tumors arise.
Entanglements stem from oneself—
When will a hundred sorrows fade?

Without form, how can there be a shadow? From whence does the shadow arise?
Without water, how can waves be born? From whence do the waves emerge?
The empty holds no substance—rumors must be false,
The real contains the hollow—words must come from without.

**Thirteenth Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Gradual Ease After Long Hardship – Neutral**
The困 dragon coils long in the mire,
The mountain low, the tiger’s path lost.
Gradually climbing through clouds and mist,
The red sun has not yet set in the west.

The flood dragon, denied clouds and rain, lies trapped in secluded crags,
The leopard and tiger, lost in the wilds, lurk in the undergrowth.
The noble one, dwelling in cultivation, finds the Dao flourishing—advancement assured,
The scholar, refining his craft, awaits the hour—merit and fame will naturally appear.

**Fourteenth Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Stranded and Unbearable – Most Inauspicious**
When will the many ailments heal?
Mist and waves bar the distant road.
The horse weary, the traveler spent,
The waning sun, the howling fox and ape.

The heart finds no joy, like a lingering illness,
Affairs unfulfilled, as if blocked by perilous paths.
The horse exhausted, the traveler weary—unable to advance, unable to press on,
The setting sun, the cries of apes and foxes—unable to proceed, unable to halt.

**Fifteenth Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Noble Support – Most Auspicious**
An arrow descends from the clear sky,
On the road, one meets horses and oxen.
Wheeled carts carry treasures,
The wind swift, the sailing boat speeds forth.

Seeking fame and office, one gains promotion through recommendation,
Treading hardship, a fine steed appears for the journey.
Treasures overflow, the cartwheels turn swiftly as if flying,
Clouds and wind favor the waters—the vessel glides smooth and fast as a galloping horse.

**Sixteenth Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Advancing or Retreating, Both Favorable – Most Auspicious**
A horse crosses the mountain ahead,
The golden crow shines upon the distant pass.
High or low, no obstacles—
Song and dance reflect joyous faces.

The golden crow ascends the Milky Way, casting bright light below,
The steed races like the wind—swift passage ahead.
Whether climbing or hastening, high or low, all is within reach,
Whether advancing or yielding, above or below, no constraints remain.

**Seventeenth Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Hopes Dashed Ahead – Most Inauspicious**
When will the great elegance be seen?
How many days will refined culture flourish?
Only because white hairs bring sorrow,
The scholar, clutching his belly, languishes in hardship.

Prose riddled with errors—no hope for imperial examination success,
The great elegance in decline—only the hollow pleasure of lingering.
Hopes for merit and fame dashed—white-haired and unaccomplished,
Lamenting studies delayed—years wasted, old age arrives.

**Eighteenth Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Peace and Quiet Bring Reward – Neutral**
Contentment is the foremost mechanism,
Only then does one recognize the stillness of dusk.
Let not the mirror of the heart be clouded,
Let others peer through narrow tubes.

A mind settled, thoughts clear—like unlocking the heart’s mechanism,
A will steadfast, spirit nurtured—only then does one grasp the zither’s essence.
Abandon worldly ties—let not the mirror be dimmed, clarity comes of itself,
Cultivate perfect enlightenment—delve into subtleties, wisdom’s light will appear.

**Nineteenth Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Actions Obscured – Most Inauspicious**
The beauty resents the closed door,
Emotions severed, no connection.
Advancing or retreating, no support—
Hard to find the true path’s trace.

The beauty harbors resentment, wary of petty schemes—unease lingers,
Emotions cut off, no communication—indecision in action and concealment.
Dark and tangled affairs entangle endlessly—doubt in both advance and retreat,
Gloomy thoughts coil without cease—joy and sorrow unsettled.

**Twentieth Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Failure in Affairs – Most Inauspicious**
Beset by dire straits,
Yet boasting of bold spirit.
Mocking others for having no way out,
Men and ghosts rage in attack.

In peril, one should cultivate goodness to dispel misfortune,
In crisis, one should act with caution to avoid calamity.
Boasting of heroism, unaware of fate’s blows—setbacks multiply,
Jealousy and harm, seeking to injure others—men and spirits unite in wrath.

**Twenty-First Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Unexpected Joy – Most Auspicious**
A celestial missive descends from beyond the clouds,
Many carriages bearing imperial decrees arrive at the gate.
Fragrance fills the orchid chamber,
Hand in hand, one enters the toad’s palace.

A red decree descends from heaven—glory in imperial favor,
Carriages of the honored arrive—nobility graces the household.
Affairs proceed as wished, like entering a chamber of orchids and fragrance,
Plans succeed as hoped, like ascending the moon’s osmanthus palace.

**Twenty-Second Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Wealth and Status as Desired – Most Auspicious**
Precious jade, treasured and hoarded,
Year after year, the fragrant rice ripens.
Emerald shade stretches a thousand miles,
Peach and plum trees stand in rows.

A treasure mountain appears—admired like a foot-long jade,
The fragrant rice ripens—celebrating a bountiful year.
Affairs flourish—verdant shade stretches a thousand miles in harmony,
Wealth abounds—peach and plum trees stand in rows, blossoms bearing fruit.

**Twenty-Third Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Timing Brings Success – Neutral**
An affair not yet resolved,
Livelihood grows ever harder.
Yet if one follows the seasons,
Where is there no ease?

A matter remains unfinished, its course not yet complete,
Life’s path grows ever more arduous.
But if one yields to the heavens’ timing,
What place lacks tranquility?

**Ninth Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Grievances Remain Unresolved – Wretched Fortune**
Only because thorns have grown,
Jackals and wolves now threaten even the descendants.

chunks.original_text: 人情艰阻如登蜀道之难，谋事忧劳若渡峡江之险。 天时助生涯自遂可优可闲，人事顺谋用自周有消有息。 丑时二十四　终有所济　中平 久旱欲焦枯，田园半有无。 井泉从地出，当看泽来苏。 天久旱农力疲竭田裂纹苗稼焦枯，偶井泉涌出地神力扶而旱不为灾。 忽甘泽沾濡天意，救助而秋必有望。 丑时二十五　灾去吉来　上上 花发又花残，悲欢一半颜。 十分留晚景，新意到人间。 人有悲欢离合花谢花开，时有否泰赛亨月圆月缺，当其晚岁忻逢富寿庆康宁，正植桑榆喜遇春和增快乐。 丑时二十六　诸事渐亨　中平 祈福可偷安，随缘意自宽。 门庭香火供，无事也清欢。 省过则灾愆自息诸事渐亨，随缘则妄想不生百魔降伏。 精祈香火香火旺而神力坚，自乐清欢清欢多而道心足。 丑时二十七　平平　有得 生涯付倘来，颜笑逐时开。 随分春台乐，天然获宝财。 富贵功名身外倘来之物，死生寿夭命中注定之因。 宽其心者喜庆多而病不生，安其分者熙然乐而灾不染。 丑时二十八　望事羁赛　下下 人老又蹉跎，刚须口吻多。 平地犹有触，动得鬼神呵。 生涯赠蹬徒嗟人老花残，术业蹉跎谩叹时迁岁改。 履平地若有坑有坎触处风波，举谋用则无功无成人神呵责。 丑时二十九　忙失故道　下下 心折已堪伤，穷途暮复长。 望人人不助，知有几回肠。 仓皇失措心百虑以堪伤，路阻途穷意生萦而堪恨。 道既失人情寡助空自回伤，事不遂亲者乖疏谩劳役虑。 丑时三十　所求称心　上上 青牛负宝财，良马出龙胎。 异梦生英杰，翔飞应上台。 青牛负其宝货力载万钧，骏马生於龙胎日行千里。 英杰出世应三台嘉应之祥，功名遂心达四方契合之美。 寅时第一　非常之遇　上上 不是飞蓬客，新开天上雄。 凌烟倍声价，华宠揖三公。 人之济遇平地可以登仙，事之得时谈笑可以获禄。 非常者不期而会喜跃欢生，王公者利见大人恩华宠遇。 寅时第二　势孤援寡　下下 鼎沸若狂波，孤舟要渡河。 异乡无故友，人事拂天和。 鼎沸之心谩有吞舟之大志，奔趋之势更无济渡之扁舟。 若孤军绝援於坚围，如羁旅无寥於异域。 寅时第三　小人道长　下下 冰霜寒裂肤，戎马困长途。 患深蜂蔓毒，秪自叹泥涂。 履霜坚冰寒非一日浸，润肤受毁非一朝伪说。 巧言之谤深於蜂姜之有毒，谗语佞口之非甚於犬戎之为害。 寅时第四　君子道消　下下 否剥数时穷，阴阳窒不通。 独谋宁获助，红日蚀长空。 天地闭塞曰否否则有迍，阴阳差谬曰剥剥则有咎。 既否且剥君子所以道穷，阳挫阴差小人所以道长。 寅时第五　小事契心　中平 胡越可为家，芝兰味更佳。 虽无霜雪干，且喜傍墙花。 合而不离曰契胡越可伺，美而不乱曰佳芝兰并室。 虽非比於松相傲雪凌霜，亦可庆於芳菲赏心悦目＃２。 寅时第六　改故则吉　中平 业垢碍前程，好邪事不成。 但存公直理，咫尺契神明。 路无荆棘之所碍大道可行，事有纤芥之所疑亏邪勿用。 宜改宜革吉福渐次来祥，存正存心神明目然垂佑。 寅时第七　奋跃亨衢　上上 珍藏几年功，一夕气吐虹。 北斗寒无翳，请看三天锋。 奋於学者必有成功之望，奋於志者岂无腾逢之时。 神锋三尺荧荧扫荡千邪，北斗七星凛凛斡旋造化。 寅时第八　先悲后吉　中平
chunks.translated_text:
**Twenty-Fourth Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Eventual Relief – Neutral**
Human feelings are as fraught as climbing the perilous roads of Shu,
Plans and affairs weigh heavy as crossing the treacherous Yangtze gorges.
Yet when Heaven’s timing aids one’s livelihood, ease and leisure naturally follow;
When human affairs align with purpose, all finds resolution and rest.

**Twenty-Fourth Oracle – Eventual Relief – Neutral**
Long drought parches the land to withering,
Fields lie half-barren, half-bare.
Then from the earth wells spring forth—
Behold the life-giving rains revive all.

Prolonged drought exhausts the farmer’s strength, fields crack, seedlings wither;
Yet when a wellspring bursts from the earth, divine power averts disaster.
Suddenly, sweet rains descend—Heaven’s mercy—
And autumn’s harvest glimmers with hope.

**Twenty-Fifth Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Misfortune Departs, Fortune Arrives – Most Auspicious**
Flowers bloom, then fade,
Joy and sorrow share one face.
Yet in life’s late season,
New blessings grace the world.

Human hearts know parting and reunion, flowers wither and bloom;
Time brings fortune and misfortune, the moon waxes and wanes.
In one’s later years, happiness arrives—wealth, longevity, peace, and health—
Just as planting mulberry in twilight brings spring’s joy anew.

**Twenty-Sixth Oracle of the Hour of Chou – All Affairs Gradually Flourish – Neutral**
Prayers may bring fleeting peace,
Following fate eases the mind.
Incense burns at the household altar—
Even without cause, there is pure joy.

Amending faults stills calamity, all affairs gradually flourish;
Following fate dissolves delusion, a hundred demons submit.
Devout prayers strengthen the spirits’ power,
And in pure joy, the Daoist heart finds fulfillment.

**Twenty-Seventh Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Moderate – Some Gain**
Livelihood comes as if by chance,
Smiles bloom with the passing hours.
Content with spring’s simple pleasures,
One naturally gains treasured wealth.

Wealth and rank are but fleeting gifts from without,
Life and death, longevity and fate are decreed within.
A heart at ease brings joy and wards off illness,
Accepting one’s lot brings happiness and averts misfortune.

**Twenty-Eighth Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Hopes Hindered – Most Inauspicious**
Age brings stumbling steps,
Words grow sharp, complaints many.
Even on level ground, obstacles arise—
Every move draws the gods’ rebuke.

Life’s path is strewn with setbacks, one sighs at age and fading blossoms;
Skills and crafts falter, time slips by, years change.
Walking level ground, one still stumbles—every step stirs wind and waves;
Attempts at plans yield no success, and gods and men alike condemn.

**Twenty-Ninth Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Hasty Deviation from the Dao – Most Inauspicious**
The heart breaks, already wounded,
The road ahead stretches long in twilight.
Hoping for aid, none comes—
How many turns of the gut?

Panic and confusion wound the heart with a hundred cares,
Blocked paths and dead ends breed resentment.
The Dao lost, human kindness fades—vain are the turns of sorrow;
Affairs unfulfilled, even kin grow distant—futile are the toils of worry.

**Thirtieth Oracle of the Hour of Chou – Desires Fulfilled – Most Auspicious**
A black ox bears treasured wealth,
A fine steed springs from dragon’s lineage.
Strange dreams herald heroes—
Soaring high, they ascend the celestial terrace.

A black ox carries its precious cargo, strength to bear ten thousand jun;
A noble horse, born of dragon’s blood, races a thousand li a day.
Heroes emerge, answering the auspicious omen of the Three Terraces,
Success and renown align with the four directions’ harmony.

**First Oracle of the Hour of Yin – Extraordinary Encounter – Most Auspicious**
No drifting tumbleweed am I—
A new hero rises in Heaven’s realm.
Before the *Lingyan* Pavilion, fame doubles,
With splendid favor, one bows to the Three Dukes.

A person’s fortune may lift them to immortality from level ground;
A matter’s timing may bring rank through laughter and ease.
The extraordinary arrives unbidden, joy overflows;
Before the king’s ministers, one receives splendid favor and honor.

**Second Oracle of the Hour of Yin – Isolated, Few Allies – Most Inauspicious**
Like a cauldron’s boiling waves,
A lone boat seeks to cross the river.
In a foreign land, no old friends—
Human affairs defy Heaven’s harmony.

A heart like a boiling cauldron harbors ambitions vast as the sea,
Yet in haste, no ferryboat appears to aid the crossing.
Like an army cut off, besieged by foes,
Or a traveler adrift, friendless in a strange land.

**Third Oracle of the Hour of Yin – The Petty Person’s Dao Grows – Most Inauspicious**
Frost and ice chill to the bone,
Warhorses weary on endless roads.
Perils deepen like creeping vines—
One can only sigh in the mire.

Frost’s hardening into ice is no sudden chill,
Nor is slander’s wound a single day’s deceit.
Crafty words sting deeper than a wasp’s venom,
Flattery and malice harm more than the Xiongnu’s raids.

**Fourth Oracle of the Hour of Yin – The Noble Person’s Dao Wanes – Most Inauspicious**
The *Pi* and *Bo* hexagrams’ time is exhausted,
Yin and Yang block all passage.
A lone plan finds no aid—
The red sun eclipses the vast sky.

When Heaven and Earth close, it is *Pi*—stagnation brings misfortune;
When Yin and Yang clash, it is *Bo*—dissolution brings blame.
In *Pi* and *Bo*, the noble person’s Dao reaches its end,
While the petty person’s Dao waxes as Yang wanes and Yin errs.

**Fifth Oracle of the Hour of Yin – Small Matters Align with the Heart – Neutral**
Though distant as Hu and Yue, they may yet be kin,
Orchid and iris share a fragrance all the more fine.
Though lacking the frost-defying pine’s resolve,
One may still delight in the blossoms by the wall.

To unite without parting is *qi*—Hu and Yue may yet be one home;
To be beautiful without disorder is *jia*—orchid and iris share a chamber.
Though not the pine that scorns frost and snow,
One may still rejoice in the fragrant blooms that gladden the heart.

**Sixth Oracle of the Hour of Yin – Reform Brings Auspiciousness – Neutral**
The grime of past deeds blocks the path ahead,
Vicious and crooked affairs bear no fruit.
But uphold fairness and integrity—
In an instant, one aligns with the divine.

Where no thorns block the road, the great Dao lies open;
Where the slightest doubt lingers, abandon the crooked path.
Reform and renew—auspicious fortune will gradually arrive;
Uphold rectitude and sincerity—the gods will surely bless.

**Seventh Oracle of the Hour of Yin – Striving Opens the Path to Prosperity – Most Auspicious**
Years of hidden toil—
In one night, a rainbow’s breath.
The Northern Dipper shines clear, unobscured—
Behold the gleam of the Three Heavens’ blade!

One who strives in study will surely see success;
One who strives in ambition will not lack a moment of triumph.
A three-foot divine blade flashes, sweeping away a thousand evils;
The Northern Dipper’s seven stars turn, guiding the workings of creation.

chunks.original_text: 春风虽未浓，空想旧颜容。 直待秋云卷，日明重又重。 春风始生和气万物未萌，秋月方见月辉百祥集至。 若占望则先晦后明明而方遂，凡用事则初否末泰泰而始生。 寅时第九　内外失助　下下 居家睽六亲，作物又妨身。 动摇不自得，旧迹几时新。 家庭扰扰亲者疏而爱者离，自身惶惶智者愚而七者拙。 失助者弱力而荷千钧焉能负载，远动者巨浪而漂一叶岂能平稳。 寅时第十　人财不安　下下 有虑亲邻隔，无财力渐疲。 强生分别路，何处觅平夷。 虑近不可不虑正若比邻，财损正恐失财一如窃好。 分别者道险路危则坦平未见，不安者心离事阻而乖异并生。 寅时十一　惊忧失宜　下下 龙卧明珠失，虎行人迹空。 何时得安枕，惊惨夕阳中。 虎无爪则威令不行困居幽谷，龙失珠则神能顿减默隐探渊。 惊惧如临棘座之中，愁惨若卧针毡之上。 寅时十二　腾达有望　上上 高攀龙凤姿，岂似鹪鹩儿。 平地皆烟雨，一夕游天池。 鸿鹄之志岂从燕雀之徒，鹍鹏之才焉与鹪鹩之比。 飞黄腾达於万里因高贵以提携，奋发逍遥於四俱得跻攀而称俗遂。 寅时十三　望用得财　上上 一着已先机，暮分黑白围，大江逢好渡，展翼却高飞。 谋事有若变暮算在前而成在后，进望全如射弓端在此而中在彼。 津渡得舟更勿忧乎不济，飞腾助翼何劳虑其不冲。 寅时十四　先虚后实　上上 雷发震天衢，阴云密不舒。 忽然膏雨至，霈泽领天书。 霶雨降必布叆叇之浓云，恩禄宠临必先勤劳於王事。 膏雨至苏田润物岁稔时丰，丹书赐褒善美功道高德重。 寅时十五　人事不和　下下 樽酒谩追随，花问争是非。 解冤冤未解，争柰小人欺。 因杯酌而生讥诮立见喧争，防谈笑而变是非坐遭吻舌。 因而成怨怨结重若丘山，造次为殃殃探积如沧海。 寅时十六　事虑非厄　下下 屋裹虑添蛇，马嘶空自嗟。 炎炎烟火地，红日障量买遮。 腾蛇达宅门户岂得而安，赢马嘶呜行人焉得而至。 火炎空而虚惊将至昼谨夜防，云遮障而暗昧恐临日忧夕惧。 寅时十七　渐收天信　上上 离亭久索居，云隔鸣来书。 昨夜灯花结，明朝引玉琚。 羁旅天涯久绝一音之好，征鸿飞至忽收万宝之书。 灯结重重之蕊喜信临门，鹊呜切切之声佳音入户。 寅时十八　往而获吉　上上 欲速尚迟迟，投机自释疑。 绿深溪岸稳，何处不相宜。 踌蹰未失欲进或欲退，去处两疑待举又时默。 幸有壶天之景色遍赏何妨，殊无绝地之闲忧畅怀何碍。 寅时十九　事无疑碍　上上 玉鉴尘无染，金刀利可裁。 天然成美事，争得惹尘埃。 镜莹净则可以鉴容妍丑乃分，刀快利则可以裁物刚次乃应。 尘埃不染纷扰障碍已除，美事欲周悦择情怀始畅。 寅时二十　临事疑滞　下下 隔岸闻呜乌，道途隔几滩。 神呵犹自笑，无路到仙坛。 乌呜兽吼徒生吻舌之音，道阻途迷忽起嗟嘘之叹。 神呵者怒而不恤愆重过探，路绝者往而不通道微德薄。 寅时二十一　失财不律　下下 多聚还多失，寻财事更迟。 归有如醉梦，闲虑却愁思。 贪敛之人专务得而还务失，欺邪之事不获吉而必获殃。 心事倒乱昏昏醉梦颠迷，念若差迭扰扰愁思萦挠。 寅时二十二　人财亏损　下下 乌飞不可追，云雨暗垂垂。 寻真还失路，何处不堪悲。 乌飞兔走日月逝而莫追，云暗雨垂天地暝而难晓。
chunks.translated_text:
Spring winds, though not yet thick,
Still evoke the visage of old.
Wait until autumn clouds roll back—
Daylight brightens, layer upon layer.

Spring winds first stir harmonious qi, yet the myriad things remain unborn;
Autumn moon at last reveals its radiance, and a hundred auspices gather.
If divining hopes, first darkness, then clarity—only when bright does fulfillment come;
In all undertakings, first adversity, then prosperity—only when flourishing does life begin.

**Ninth Oracle of the Hour of Yin – Forsaken Within and Without – Most Inauspicious**
At home, kin grow estranged;
In work, harm befalls the self.
Restless and ill at ease,
When will old traces renew?

Households in turmoil—loved ones drift apart, dear ones depart;
The self in disarray—wisdom turns to folly, skill to clumsiness.
Forsaken, strength wanes—how can one bear a thousand jun’s weight?
Far-traveling, tossed by towering waves—how can a single leaf stay steady?

**Tenth Oracle of the Hour of Yin – Unsettled in Person and Wealth – Most Inauspicious**
Worries keep kin and neighbors distant;
Wealth dwindles, strength fades.
Forced to tread separate paths—
Where to find level ground?

Worries near at hand must be heeded, as if they were next-door neighbors;
Wealth lost is feared as if stolen by thieves.
Separation brings perilous roads and treacherous ways—where is the level path?
Unsettled, hearts drift, affairs falter, and discord arises.

**Eleventh Oracle of the Hour of Yin – Startled and Anxious, Ill-Timed – Most Inauspicious**
The dragon’s bright pearl is lost in slumber;
The tiger’s tracks vanish in the wild.
When will one rest easy—
Startled and sorrowful as the setting sun?

A tiger without claws loses its might, trapped in a secluded valley;
A dragon bereft of its pearl sees its power suddenly fade, hidden in the abyss.
Startled, as if seated on thorns;
Sorrowful, as if lying on a bed of needles.

**Twelfth Oracle of the Hour of Yin – Soaring Ambitions in Sight – Most Auspicious**
Climbing high with the bearing of dragon and phoenix—
How could one resemble the wren’s brood?
The earth is veiled in mist and rain—
In a single night, one soars to the celestial pond.

The swan-goose’s ambition scorns the sparrow’s flock;
The roc’s talent cannot be compared to the wren’s.
Soaring on the wings of the *feihuang*, traversing ten thousand li—elevated by the noble;
Thriving in freedom across the four directions—ascending to join the common and the refined.

**Thirteenth Oracle of the Hour of Yin – Hopes Fulfilled, Wealth Attained – Most Auspicious**
One move seizes the initiative;
By dusk, black and white are decided.
Upon the great river, a favorable crossing—
Spread your wings and soar high.

Planning affairs is like a game of *weiqi*—the evening’s calculation precedes success;
Advancing hopes is like archery—aim here, strike there.
With a boat at the ford, why fear failure to cross?
With wings to aid flight, why worry of not soaring?

**Fourteenth Oracle of the Hour of Yin – First Hollow, Then Substantial – Most Auspicious**
Thunder shakes the heavens’ thoroughfare;
Dark clouds press close, unyielding.
Suddenly, the life-giving rain arrives—
A deluge of blessings, bearing the celestial decree.

A downpour descends only after dense, brooding clouds gather;
Favor and rank arrive only after diligent service to the throne.
The life-giving rain revives the fields, nourishing all things—years of plenty, seasons of abundance;
The vermilion decree bestows praise—virtue is lofty, merit profound.

**Fifteenth Oracle of the Hour of Yin – Discord in Human Affairs – Most Inauspicious**
Wine cups feigned in camaraderie,
Amid blossoms, quarrels arise.
Resolving grudges, grudges remain;
How to endure the petty man’s deceit?

From toasts, mockery arises—strife erupts at once;
From laughter, disputes emerge—tongues wag in an instant.
Thus, enmity forms—grudges pile high as mountains;
Hasty actions breed calamity—woes accumulate like the sea.

**Sixteenth Oracle of the Hour of Yin – Worries Without True Misfortune – Most Inauspicious**
Within the house, a snake’s dread lingers;
The horse neighs in vain lament.
In the scorching land of smoke and fire—
The red sun’s light is obscured.

A flying serpent invades the home—how can doors and windows be secure?
A lean horse neighs—how can travelers arrive?
Fire blazes in vain—false alarms arise, demanding vigilance day and night;
Clouds veil and obscure—fears loom, dreading the day, trembling at dusk.

**Seventeenth Oracle of the Hour of Yin – Heaven’s Tidings Gradually Return – Most Auspicious**
Long exiled at the wayside pavilion,
Clouds parted as the calling bird brought a letter.
Last night, the lamp’s wick blossomed—
Tomorrow, the jade pendant will be drawn.

Wandering the ends of the earth, long cut off from a single word of good news;
The migrating swan arrives, suddenly bearing a letter of ten thousand treasures.
The lamp’s wick unfurls layer upon layer—joyful tidings arrive at the door;
The magpie’s cries ring clear—glad news enters the household.

**Eighteenth Oracle of the Hour of Yin – Venturing Forth Brings Auspiciousness – Most Auspicious**
To hasten is to delay;
Seizing the moment dispels doubt.
By the deep green, stable riverbank—
Where is there not harmony?

Hesitant, torn between advancing or retreating;
Uncertain of the path, waiting to act, yet silent.
Fortunately, the scenery of a hidden realm is everywhere—why not enjoy it?
No desolate lands or idle worries—why not embrace contentment?

**Nineteenth Oracle of the Hour of Yin – Affairs Unhindered – Most Auspicious**
The jade mirror, unstained by dust;
The golden blade, sharp enough to cut.
Naturally, a beautiful affair unfolds—
How could it gather dust?

A mirror polished and clear can discern beauty and ugliness;
A blade swift and sharp can cut through hardness and softness.
Unsullied by dust, obstructions and hindrances are removed;
A perfect affair nears completion—only then does the heart rejoice.

**Twentieth Oracle of the Hour of Yin – Hesitation in Affairs – Most Inauspicious**
Across the river, the cawing of crows;
The road ahead, blocked by shoals.
The gods mock in jest—
No path leads to the immortal’s altar.

Crows caw, beasts howl—only idle chatter;
Roads blocked, paths lost—sighs of lament arise.
The gods scold in anger, heedless of grave faults;
The way is cut off—one’s virtue is meager, one’s power slight.

**Twenty-First Oracle of the Hour of Yin – Wealth Lost, Discipline Lacking – Most Inauspicious**
The more one amasses, the more one loses;
Seeking wealth, affairs grow sluggish.
Returning home, as if in a drunken dream—
Idle worries breed sorrowful thoughts.

The greedy, ever grasping—what they gain, they soon lose;
Deceitful schemes bring no fortune, only calamity.
Thoughts in disarray, muddled as in a drunken dream;
Minds astray, restless with tangled, sorrowful reflections.

**Twenty-Second Oracle of the Hour of Yin – Loss of Person and Wealth – Most Inauspicious**
The flying crow cannot be pursued;
Clouds and rain darken the sky.
Seeking truth, one loses the way—
Where is there no cause for sorrow?

Crows fly, hares run—the sun and moon pass, irretrievable;
Clouds darken, rain falls—the heavens and earth dim, inscrutable.
